spanishExample: ¡No vengas! Vimos algo aquí que no es seguro.
englishTranslation: Don’t come! We saw something here that isn’t safe.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
seguro: adjective meaning "safe" or "secure" when used with Ser
vimos: saw, we saw (Ver, preterite, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: ¡Por supuesto! No quiere que vengamos.
englishTranslation: Of course! She doesn’t want us to come.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: ¡Ven a clase mañana!
englishTranslation: Come to class tomorrow!

spanishExample: ¡Ven a nuestra casa! Estamos a gusto.
englishTranslation: Come to our house! We are comfortable.

spanishExample: ¡Ven! Se supone que eres parte de nuestra familia.
englishTranslation: Come! You’re supposed to be part of our family.
vocabIncluded: suponerse: any use of Suponer with a reflexive, plus "que", pronoun, changing the meaning to "supposedly"

spanishExample: ¡Venga a nuestra casa para la fiesta!
englishTranslation: (Formal) Come to our house for the party!

spanishExample: ¡Vengan con nosotros!
englishTranslation: (Plural) Come with us!

spanishExample: ¿Realmente lo viste? ¡Qué suerte!
englishTranslation: Did you really see it? How lucky!
vocabIncluded: viste: saw, you saw (Ver, preterite, 2nd person)

spanishExample: ¿Vienes? No tienes que venir.
englishTranslation: Are you coming? You don’t have to come.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Como lo ves, vinimos muy tarde.
englishTranslation: As you see it, we came very late.
vocabIncluded: ves: see, you see (Ver, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Ella lo ve, pero nosotros no lo vemos.
englishTranslation: She sees it, but we don’t see it.
vocabIncluded: ve: sees, he/she/it sees (Ver, present, 3rd person)
vemos: see, we see (Ver, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Ella no quiere que yo lo vea.
englishTranslation: She doesn’t want me to see it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
vea: see, I see (Ver, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: Ella quiere que yo venga otra vez esta semana, porque había venido sin mí.
englishTranslation: She wants me to come again this week, because she had come without me.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
había: "had", "he/she/it had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 3rd person)
venga: come, I come (Venir, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: Ella vino, pero no pudo verlo.
englishTranslation: She came, but she couldn’t see it.
vocabIncluded: pudo: "was able / managed", "he/she/it was able / managed" (Poder, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Estará feliz cuando lo vea con cariño.
englishTranslation: She’ll be happy when she sees it with affection.
vocabIncluded: estará: "will be", "he/she/it will be" (Estar, future, 3rd person)
vea: see, he/she/it see (Ver, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Hay que suponer que han venido.
englishTranslation: There is a need to suppose that they have come.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)
hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)
using Haber with "que" to indicate that there's a need to do something

spanishExample: Igual, a ver si podemos hacerlo.
englishTranslation: Still, let’s see if we can do it.

spanishExample: Les dije que vean lo que quieren ver.
englishTranslation: I told them to see what they want to see.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
vean: see, they see (Ver, subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: No lo podremos hacer, ni siquiera cuando ella venga.
englishTranslation: We won’t be able to do it, not even when she comes.
vocabIncluded: podremos: "will be able", "we will be able" (Poder, future, 1st person plural)
venga: come, he/she/it come (Venir, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No quiere que vengan a la fiesta.
englishTranslation: She doesn’t want them to come to the party.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: No quieren que veamos lo que han visto.
englishTranslation: They don’t want us to see what they have seen.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)
veamos: see, we see (Ver, subjunctive, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: No quiero que vengas.
englishTranslation: I don’t want you to come.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Quiero que veas si vienen.
englishTranslation: I want you to see if they are coming.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
veas: see, you see (Ver, subjunctive, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Quizás no viniste porque tenías miedo.
englishTranslation: Maybe you didn’t come because you were afraid.

spanishExample: Se suponía que vino antes de la fiesta.
englishTranslation: Supposedly she came before the party.
vocabIncluded: suponerse: any use of Suponer with a reflexive, plus "que", pronoun, changing the meaning to "supposedly"
suponía: supposed, he/she/it supposed (Suponer, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Se suponía que era demasiado bueno para nosotros.
englishTranslation: Supposedly it was too good for us.
vocabIncluded: suponerse: any use of Suponer with a reflexive, plus "que", pronoun, changing the meaning to "supposedly"
suponía: supposed, he/she/it supposed (Suponer, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Siquiera lo está viendo.
englishTranslation: At least she is seeing it.

spanishExample: Supongo que solo viene porque le dijiste eso.
englishTranslation: I guess he is only coming because you told him that.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
supongo: suppose, I suppose (Suponer, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Supuse que tenía que venir a la fiesta.
englishTranslation: I supposed that I had to come to the party.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
supuse: supposed, I supposed (Suponer, preterite, 1st person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tendremos suerte cuando usted venga con nosotros.
englishTranslation: We’ll be lucky when you(formal) come with us.
vocabIncluded: tendremos: "will have", "we will have" (Tener, future, 1st person plural)
usted: "you", formal subject pronoun, taking 3rd-person treatment
venga: come, he/she/it come (Venir, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Vengo hoy porque hice esto aquí hace dos días.
englishTranslation: I come today because I did this here two days ago.
vocabIncluded: vengo: come, I come (Venir, present, 1st person) NEEDS WORK

spanishExample: Vengo para ver lo que dijiste.
englishTranslation: I’m coming in order to see what you said.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive
vengo: come, I come (Venir, present, 1st person) NEEDS WORK

spanishExample: Veo la casa ahora.
englishTranslation: I see the house now.
vocabIncluded: veo: see, I see (Ver, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Vi que esto es un trabajo para la policía.
englishTranslation: I saw this is a job for the police.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
vi: saw, I saw (Ver, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Viene con sus amigas.
englishTranslation: She is coming with her friends(f).

spanishExample: Vieron a sus amigos.
englishTranslation: They saw their friends.
vocabIncluded: "the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person
vieron: saw, they saw (Ver, preterite, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Vine aquí, pero no quiero verte.
englishTranslation: I came here, but I don’t want to see you.

spanishExample: Vine porque supe que ellos vienen.
englishTranslation: I came here because I found out that they are coming.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
supe: "knew / found out", "I knew / found out" (Saber, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Vinieron hace tres días.
englishTranslation: They came three days ago.

spanishExample: Vio que les tengo cariño.
englishTranslation: He saw that I’m fond of them.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
tenerle cariño a alguien: to be fond of someone (idiom)
vio: saw, he/she/it saw (Ver, preterite, 3rd person)
